title: How do we create a better economy?

multiple-choice.question: What is the traditional view of a healthy economy in Western societies?

options.label: A
options.text: An economy that balances growth with resource conservation

options.label: B
options.text: An economy that prioritizes social welfare over growth

options.label: C
options.text: An economy that constantly grows and expands

options.label: D
options.text: An economy that focuses on reducing poverty and inequality

multiple-choice.question: Who was commissioned by the US Congress to come up with a single number to measure the output of the economy?
What is the name of the economic measure developed by Simon Kuznets?
According to Kate Raworth, what is the problem with using GDP as a measure of a country's economy?

options.label: A
options.text: It does not account for the value of unpaid caring work

options.label: B
options.text: It does not account for the impact of economic activity on the environment

options.label: C
options.text: It does not account for the distribution of wealth among citizens

multiple-choice.question: What is the "doughnut" model of economic prosperity proposed by Kate Raworth?

options.label: A
options.text: A model that prioritizes economic growth over social welfare

options.label: B
options.text: A model that seeks to balance human needs with environmental sustainability

options.label: C
options.text: A model that focuses on reducing poverty and inequality

options.label: D
options.text: A model that prioritizes technological innovation over social and environmental concerns

multiple-choice.question: What is the inner limit of the "doughnut" model?

options.label: A
options.text: The point at which economic growth becomes unsustainable

options.label: B
options.text: The point at which human needs are met, but not exceeded

options.label: C
options.text: The point at which environmental degradation becomes unacceptable

options.label: D
options.text: The point at which poverty and deprivation are eliminated

multiple-choice.question: What is the outer limit of the "doughnut" model?

options.label: A
options.text: The point at which economic growth becomes unsustainable

options.label: B
options.text: The point at which human needs are met, but not exceeded

options.label: C
options.text: The point at which environmental degradation becomes unacceptable

options.label: D
options.text: The point at which technological innovation becomes too rapid

multiple-choice.question: According to Kate Raworth, what is the shape of progress in the 21st century?

options.label: A
options.text: An ever-rising line of exponential growth

options.label: B
options.text: A curve that balances human needs with environmental sustainability

options.label: C
options.text: A straight line that prioritizes economic growth over social welfare

options.label: D
options.text: A downward slope that prioritizes poverty reduction over economic growth

multiple-choice.question: What is the metaphor used by Kate Raworth to describe the balance between human needs and environmental sustainability?

options.label: D
options.text: The economy as a living organism

multiple-choice.question: According to Kate Raworth, what is the key to understanding the deep interdependence of our world?

options.label: A
options.text: Recognizing the importance of economic growth

options.label: B
options.text: Prioritizing social welfare over economic growth

options.label: C
options.text: Balancing human needs with environmental sustainability

options.label: D
options.text: Embracing technological innovation as the solution to environmental problems

title: Why plague doctors wore beaked masks

multiple-choice.question: In what year is the scenario described at the beginning of the transcript taking place?
What was the approximate survival rate for the plague in the best of cases?
When did the iconic plague doctor with the beaked mask and wizard-like robes emerge on the scene?

options.label: A
options.text: During the 14th century pandemic known as the Black Death

options.label: B
options.text: During the 17th century outbreaks in Western Europe

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the herbs and compounds in the plague doctor's beak?

options.label: B
options.text: To ward off poisoned air known as miasma

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Greco-Roman physician that inspired the recipe for the herbs and compounds in the plague doctor's beak?
What was the true culprit behind the spread of the plague, unknown to doctors at the time?

options.label: A
options.text: A tiny flea transmitting the bacteria Yersinia pestis

options.label: B
options.text: A virus spread through the air

options.label: C
options.text: A bacterial infection spread through contaminated water

options.label: D
options.text: A fungal infection spread through direct contact

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the plague doctor's oiled leather robe, boots, and gloves?

options.label: C
options.text: To block miasma from entering through the skin's pores

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the pre-modern medical mainstays used by doctors to treat the plague?
What was the purpose of cupping, a pre-modern medical treatment used by doctors to treat the plague?

options.label: A
options.text: To remove poison from the body

options.label: B
options.text: To restore the body's natural balance

options.label: C
options.text: To make swollen lymph nodes burst sooner

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that modern medicine has improved our ability to combat the plague?

options.label: A
options.text: By developing more effective treatments for the plague

options.label: B
options.text: By identifying bacterial and viral threats more quickly

options.label: C
options.text: By developing vaccines against the plague

title: The sibling rivalry that divided a town - Jay Van Bavel and Dominic Packer

multiple-choice.question: What was the occupation of the pair of brothers in the German town of Herzogenaurach before World War Two?
What was the result of the disagreement between the siblings in Herzogenaurach?

options.label: B
options.text: The family business was split in two

multiple-choice.question: Why was Herzogenaurach known as "the town of bent necks"?

options.label: B
options.text: Because residents looked down to ensure they were interacting with members of their group

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the town's cultural differences

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the disagreement between the siblings

multiple-choice.question: Who developed the minimal group paradigm to investigate the minimal conditions required to turn people against each other?

options.label: B
options.text: The pair of brothers in Herzogenaurach

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the control condition in the minimal group paradigm experiment?

options.label: B
options.text: To form personal bonds between participants

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a conflict-free baseline for further research

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the minimal group paradigm experiment, even when group membership was determined by a coin flip?

options.label: C
options.text: Participants consistently gave more to members of their own group

multiple-choice.question: What was the explanation for people showing clear preferences for the most temporary and meaningless of groups, according to Tajfel and his colleagues?
What do people regularly use to help determine their sense of identity, according to the minimal group experiments?
What can be a temporary solution to help people overcome entrenched biases, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Bringing individuals together in a new group

multiple-choice.question: What is an undeniable part of the human condition, according to the transcript?

title: How do oysters make pearls? - Rob Ulrich

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary chemical compound that makes up pearls, urchin spines, and the shells of mussels, snails, and clams?
Where are hydrothermal vents typically found, and what is their significance in the formation of calcium carbonate?

options.label: A
options.text: Near coral reefs, providing a source of oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Near mountain ranges, providing a source of minerals

options.label: C
options.text: Near oceanic ridges, where hot seawater mingles with calcium-rich basalts

options.label: D
options.text: Near estuaries, where freshwater and saltwater mix

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the mantle in the formation of an oyster's shell?

options.label: B
options.text: To secrete an organic matrix of proteins and other molecules to construct a scaffold

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the oyster's internal pH level

multiple-choice.question: What are the two crystal structures that mollusks can produce out of CaCO3, and what are their properties?

options.label: A
options.text: Calcite and aragonite, with calcite being more soluble and aragonite being more stable

options.label: B
options.text: Calcite and aragonite, with calcite being more stable and aragonite being more soluble

options.label: C
options.text: Calcite and quartz, with calcite being more stable and quartz being more soluble

options.label: D
options.text: Aragonite and silica, with aragonite being more stable and silica being more soluble

multiple-choice.question: What is nacre, and how is it produced by mollusks?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of shell that is produced by mollusks through the secretion of an organic matrix

options.label: B
options.text: A type of pearl that is produced by mollusks through the coating of an intruder with nacre-producing cells

options.label: C
options.text: A type of biomaterial that is produced by mollusks through the layering of aragonite and proteins

options.label: D
options.text: A type of crystal structure that is produced by mollusks through the manipulation of CaCO3

multiple-choice.question: What is the signature property of nacre that gives it its iridescence?

options.label: C
options.text: Its uniform layering and brick-like structure

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary defense mechanism that mollusks use to produce pearls?

options.label: A
options.text: Coating an intruder with nacre-producing cells to form a pearl sac

options.label: B
options.text: Secreting an organic matrix to construct a scaffold

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated amount of carbon dioxide that the ocean absorbs each year?

options.label: A
options.text: One tenth of our carbon dioxide emissions

options.label: B
options.text: One third of our carbon dioxide emissions

options.label: C
options.text: One half of our carbon dioxide emissions

options.label: D
options.text: Two thirds of our carbon dioxide emissions

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of charged proteins in the formation of an oyster's shell?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract and guide calcium carbonate molecules into layers

options.label: B
options.text: To repel and inhibit calcium carbonate molecules from forming layers

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the oyster's internal pH level

multiple-choice.question: What is the property of nacre that makes it one of the strongest and lightest biomaterials known?

options.label: B
options.text: Its uniform layering and brick-like structure

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to absorb and distribute stress

title: Will there be another pandemic in your lifetime?

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of undiscovered viruses that currently infect mammals and birds?
According to historical data, what is the longest stretch of time without a documented outbreak that killed at least 10,000 people?
What is the estimated probability of a COVID-19-level pandemic occurring in a given year, based on historical data?
What percentage of undiscovered viruses are estimated to have the potential to spill over and infect humans?
According to the model generated by scientists, what is the estimated probability of another COVID-19-level pandemic occurring in a given year?
What is the estimated lifetime probability of living through at least one more COVID-19-level pandemic in the next 75 years, based on a 2% yearly probability?
What is the name of the diagram used to model all possible scenarios and estimate the lifetime probability of a pandemic?
According to scientists, what measures saved over a million lives in the first six months of the COVID-19 pandemic in the US?

options.label: C
options.text: Early warning systems, contact tracing, social distancing, and other public health measures

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of lives saved by vaccines during the COVID-19 pandemic?
What is the main idea of the transcript regarding pandemics?

options.label: A
options.text: Pandemics are rare and unlikely to occur

options.label: B
options.text: Pandemics are inevitable and we can't do anything to prevent them

options.label: C
options.text: Pandemics are a serious threat, but we have the power to reduce their likelihood and impact

options.label: D
options.text: Pandemics are only caused by viruses

title: How do we determine the value of a life? - Rebecca L. Walker

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern about the smallpox virus, despite it being eradicated for over 40 years?

options.label: A
options.text: The virus is still highly contagious.

options.label: B
options.text: The virus has mutated into a more deadly form.

options.label: C
options.text: Rogue actors might try to weaponize it.

options.label: D
options.text: The virus has become resistant to vaccines.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it unethical to expose people to the smallpox virus for research purposes?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a highly lethal virus.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has serious side effects.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has never been tested on humans before.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a rare disease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the philosophical concept used to consider the value of a life, whether human or non-human?
According to Immanuel Kant, what grants humans moral status?

options.label: B
options.text: Their rational nature and ability to will their actions

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to recognize individual members of their community

multiple-choice.question: Who argued that a capacity for suffering makes an entity worthy of moral consideration?
What is the common opinion regarding the value of a human's life compared to a monkey's?

options.label: A
options.text: A monkey's life is more valuable than a human's.

options.label: B
options.text: A human's life is more valuable than a monkey's.

options.label: C
options.text: Both human and monkey lives have equal value.

options.label: D
options.text: The value of a life depends on the circumstances.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with the calculation of sacrificing monkeys to save human lives?

options.label: A
options.text: It is morally required to sacrifice any number of monkeys to save one human.

options.label: B
options.text: It is morally acceptable to sacrifice one monkey to save five humans.

options.label: C
options.text: The calculation becomes unstable when considering large numbers of monkeys.

options.label: D
options.text: The calculation is not relevant to the decision-making process.

multiple-choice.question: What complicates the decision-making process in the scenario presented?

options.label: A
options.text: The guarantee that the research will save human lives.

options.label: B
options.text: The uncertainty that the research will save human lives.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that the disease has been eradicated.

options.label: D
options.text: The use of monkeys as research subjects.

multiple-choice.question: What do some philosophers argue is not the best way to make moral decisions?
What is essential for any decision made in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is based on moral absolutism

options.label: B
options.text: That it is based on moral relativism

title: Why the Moon turns red during a total lunar eclipse

multiple-choice.question: What was the ancient Mayans' and Mesopotamians' reaction when they saw a blood moon lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: They celebrated it as a good omen.

options.label: B
options.text: They thought it was a sign of good fortune.

options.label: C
options.text: They feared something monstrous and evil was eating the moon.

options.label: D
options.text: They believed it was a sign of the end of the world.

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how long does a lunar eclipse last?
Why doesn't the moon disappear from view during a total lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the earth's atmosphere blocks the sunlight.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the earth's atmosphere bends the red wavelengths of light around the planet.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the moon's surface reflects the sunlight.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sun's light is too strong.

multiple-choice.question: What is the red ring around the earth during a total lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: A sign of a solar flare.

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of light from every sunrise and sunset on earth.

options.label: C
options.text: A result of the earth's atmosphere scattering blue light.

options.label: D
options.text: A shadow of the moon on the earth's surface.

multiple-choice.question: Why do sunrises and sunsets on earth appear red?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the scattering of blue light by the earth's atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the reflection of sunlight by the moon's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the bending of red wavelengths of light around the planet.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the absorption of blue light by the earth's atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: Who discovered the phenomenon of Rayleigh Scattering?
Why does the sky appear blue during the daytime?

options.label: A
options.text: Because air molecules in the earth's atmosphere scatter red light more easily than blue.

options.label: B
options.text: Because air molecules in the earth's atmosphere scatter blue light more easily than red.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the earth's atmosphere absorbs blue light.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sun's light is too strong.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the sun's light during sunrise and sunset?

options.label: A
options.text: It travels through less of the earth's atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: It travels through more of the earth's atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: It is absorbed by the earth's atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: It is reflected by the moon's surface.

multiple-choice.question: Why can you easily gaze upon the sun at sunset compared to at high noon?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the sun's light is stronger at sunset.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the sun's light is weaker at sunset.

options.label: C
options.text: Because more overall sunlight is scattered at sunset.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the earth's atmosphere absorbs more sunlight at sunset.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a blood moon lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: It's the only time when you can see the sunrise and sunset simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: It's the only time when the moon disappears from view.

options.label: C
options.text: It's the only time when the earth's atmosphere scatters blue light.

options.label: D
options.text: It's the only time when the sun's light is stronger.

title: How college loans exploit students for profit - Sajay Samuel

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many Americans are indebted for their passage to the new economy?
What is the total amount owed by Americans to lenders for student loans?
What was the primary way Paul's father paid for his education at Colorado State University?
According to the speaker, what is the primary reason students like Kate have to take on a loan?

options.label: D
options.text: The cost of higher education has become unaffordable for many American families

multiple-choice.question: What is the reported combined profit of Sallie Mae and Navient, two major student loan companies?
According to the speaker, what is the primary way colleges and universities profit from student loans?

options.label: C
options.text: From both tuition and interest on debt

options.label: D
options.text: From neither tuition nor interest on debt

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "Income-Based Tuition" (IBT) proposed by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: A system where students pay a fixed tuition rate regardless of their major

options.label: B
options.text: A system where students pay a variable tuition rate based on their expected income after graduation

options.label: C
options.text: A system where students pay no tuition at all

options.label: D
options.text: A system where students pay a flat fee for all courses

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what percentage of students who enroll in post-secondary education do not complete it in a timely fashion?
What is the reported average income difference between a college graduate and a high school graduate?
According to the speaker, what is the primary benefit of implementing Income-Based Tuition?

options.label: C
options.text: To free Americans from the fear and fact of financial ruin due to defective educational products

title: Could one vaccine protect against everything?

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the public health ambition mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a vaccine that protects against every strain of the flu

options.label: B
options.text: To create a vaccine that protects against a specific strain of the flu

options.label: C
options.text: To create a single vaccine that protects against all infectious diseases

options.label: D
options.text: To create a vaccine that protects against SARS-CoV-2

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of hemagglutinin proteins on the surface of flu virus particles?

options.label: A
options.text: To attach to receptors on human cells and fuse the viral and human membranes

options.label: B
options.text: To recognize and react to the immune system

multiple-choice.question: How does the immune system remember and recognize hemagglutinin proteins?

options.label: A
options.text: By physically interacting with them and creating antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: By storing blueprints on how to make antibodies in specialized memory cells

options.label: C
options.text: By using T cells to kill infected cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which hemagglutinin proteins mutate over time, making antibodies less effective?
What is the term for the process by which two different viral genomes recombine to create a new strain of the flu?
What is the main challenge in designing a universal flu vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: Identifying conserved regions of hemagglutinin proteins

options.label: B
options.text: Getting the immune system to react to the neck region of hemagglutinin proteins

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a vaccine that protects against current and future drifted or shifted strains

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using ferritin nanoparticles in vaccine development?

options.label: B
options.text: To present viral proteins to the immune system in a harmless and engineerable way

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the experiment where mice were vaccinated with a ferritin nanoparticle and then injected with a lethal dose of H5N1?
What is the benefit of vaccines that train the T cell response in addition to the antibody response?

options.label: C
options.text: They have no effect on protection

options.label: D
options.text: They are only effective against certain strains of the flu

multiple-choice.question: Why is a fully universal vaccine against all infectious diseases currently considered science fiction?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we have no idea how our immune system would react to being trained against hundreds of different diseases at the same time

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is impossible to create such a vaccine

options.label: C
options.text: Because we lack the necessary technology

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would be too expensive

title: Is capitalism actually broken?

multiple-choice.question: What are the three inputs that an economic system converts into goods and services?
What determines whether an economic system is capitalist, communist, socialist, or something else?

options.label: C
options.text: Three dials controlling ownership, control, and market usage

multiple-choice.question: Which country is closest to having 0% private ownership of capital?
What does the second dial dictate in an economic system?

options.label: B
options.text: How much control the government has over what gets produced

options.label: C
options.text: How extensively markets are used to set prices

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for an economic system with very few regulations and a strong emphasis on individual freedom?
What was the result of the lack of regulations in the food industry during the Industrial Revolution?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of new food technologies

options.label: B
options.text: The creation of the Food and Drug Administration

options.label: C
options.text: The widespread use of embalming fluid in milk

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the major criticisms of capitalist economies in terms of their impact on the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: They incentivize the use of renewable energy sources

options.label: C
options.text: They create massive demand for the cheapest energy possible, leading to climate change

multiple-choice.question: What has been the trend in income inequality in many countries, including the US, UK, Canada, Ireland, and Australia?

options.label: A
options.text: The top 1% of income earners have seen a decrease in their share of total income

options.label: B
options.text: The top 1% of income earners have seen an increase in their share of total income

options.label: C
options.text: The bottom 50% of income earners have seen an increase in their share of total income

options.label: D
options.text: The middle class has seen an increase in their share of total income

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential consequences of a capitalist system, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The creation of a more equal society

options.label: C
options.text: The creation of a de facto aristocracy

multiple-choice.question: What is the critical question posed by the transcript regarding contemporary capitalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Can we fix contemporary capitalism by fiddling with the dials or restricting who can turn them?

options.label: B
options.text: Should we tear down the capitalist system and build a new one from scratch?

options.label: D
options.text: Is contemporary capitalism the best economic system available?

title: What causes sleepwalking? - Emmanuel During

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of people are estimated to sleepwalk at least once in their lives?
Which part of the brain is responsible for conscious, deliberate decision-making?
What stage of sleep does sleepwalking typically occur in?
What is the primary characteristic of a sleepwalker's brain activity during an episode?

options.label: A
options.text: The prefrontal cortex is highly active

options.label: B
options.text: The prefrontal cortex is inactive, but other parts of the brain are active

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is in a state of REM sleep

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the episodes that involve the brain's fight or flight system during sleep?
Why is sleepwalking more common in children?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a higher percentage of REM sleep

options.label: B
options.text: Because the brain areas that control the transition between sleep and wakefulness are still developing

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a higher percentage of slow-wave sleep

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more prone to sleep disorders

multiple-choice.question: What is a common factor that can increase the likelihood of sleepwalking?
What is the recommended approach when encountering a sleepwalker?

options.label: B
options.text: Gently guide them back to bed

multiple-choice.question: What is a common misconception about sleepwalking?

options.label: A
options.text: That it only occurs in children

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a sign of a serious sleep disorder

options.label: C
options.text: That rousing a sleepwalker causes irreparable harm

options.label: D
options.text: That sleepwalkers are always aware of their actions

multiple-choice.question: Why are many of the available treatments for sleepwalking not entirely clear in their effectiveness?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have not been rigorously studied

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not widely used

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have severe side effects

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are only effective in children

title: Why is it so hard to cure the common cold?

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the 2000 clinical trials of pleconaril, a pill designed to treat the common cold?

options.label: A
options.text: The pill was effective in treating the common cold in all patients.

options.label: B
options.text: The pill was ineffective in treating the common cold in all patients.

options.label: C
options.text: The pill helped many patients, but mutated virus variants resistant to pleconaril were found in 7 patients.

options.label: D
options.text: The pill had no effect on the common cold, and the trial was discontinued.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to a person without a fully functional immune system if they caught a cold?

options.label: A
options.text: They would experience mild symptoms and recover quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: They would experience severe symptoms, but their immune system would eventually fight off the infection.

options.label: C
options.text: The infection would quickly spread deep into their lungs, leading to tissue destruction and asphyxiation.

options.label: D
options.text: They would not be affected by the cold at all.

multiple-choice.question: How many different families of viruses can cause the common cold?
What is the function of a fever in the immune system's response to a cold?

options.label: A
options.text: To trap and flush out the virus

options.label: B
options.text: To raise the body temperature to slow down viral replication

options.label: C
options.text: To widen blood vessels and recruit white blood cells

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of all colds is caused by the rhinovirus family?
What was the outcome of William Price's 1957 trial of a rhinovirus vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: The vaccine was ineffective in preventing rhinovirus infections.

options.label: B
options.text: The vaccine was effective in preventing rhinovirus infections, but only for a short period.

options.label: C
options.text: The vaccine was effective in preventing rhinovirus infections, with only 3 out of 50 vaccinated kids getting sick.

options.label: D
options.text: The trial was inconclusive due to small sample size.

multiple-choice.question: Why did William Price's rhinovirus vaccine ultimately fail to provide broad protection?

options.label: A
options.text: The vaccine was not administered correctly.

options.label: B
options.text: The vaccine was not tested on a large enough sample size.

options.label: C
options.text: The vaccine only provided protection against one or a few subtypes of rhinovirus, out of 169 subtypes.

options.label: D
options.text: The vaccine was not effective against any subtype of rhinovirus.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the challenges in developing antiviral drugs?

options.label: A
options.text: Viruses are too small to target with drugs.

options.label: B

title: The true science of parallel universes

options.label: B
options.text: To explain the existence of multiple realities

options.text: To account for parts of the universe that we cannot see

options.label: A
options.text: A single universe with multiple realities

options.label: B
options.text: One of three distinct proposed physical models for the universe

options.label: A
options.text: Our universe is one of many bubbles in a larger universe

options.label: B
options.text: Our universe is a three-dimensional surface embedded within a larger super-universe

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The existence of multiple observable universes

options.label: C
options.text: The collapse of the wavefunction in quantum mechanics

options.label: A
options.text: Every possible alternate timeline for the universe is real

options.label: B
options.text: Our universe is one of many bubbles in a larger universe

options.label: C
options.text: Our universe is a three-dimensional surface embedded within a larger super-universe

options.label: D
options.text: The universe has only one possible timeline

options.label: B
options.text: There is some evidence for one of the models

options.label: C
options.text: There is no experimental evidence for any of the models

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By studying the properties of black holes

options.label: D
options.text: By analyzing the cosmic microwave background radiation

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of membranes and extra dimensions

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It inspired the idea of membranes and extra dimensions

options.label: D
options.text: It is not related to the multiverse models

options.label: B

options.label: C
